awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Preventing N2O Emissions by Expressing N2O Reductase in Plant Mitochondria
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrous oxide (N2O) is a potent atmospheric pollutant that is removed biologically by a bacterial enzyme called prokaryotic nitrous oxide reductase (N2OR). In high yield agricultural soils N2OR is often inadequately active. Thus, N2O has been continuously increasing in post-industrial atmosphere, so that it accounts for about 12% of present radiative forcing by greenhouse gases. N2O is also a significant ozone depleting chemical. A novel and potentially transformative solution to agricultural emissions of N2O will be investigated in this project. 

N2OR will be expressed in plant mitochondria so that it is active continuously, removing N2O from soil and atmosphere. N2OR has been reported to be active under anoxic conditions in vitro in extracts of plants conventionally transformed with nosZ, the structural gene for N2OR. Using the expertise that the investigators have developed in their lab for the construction of novel synthetic genetic vectors for phytoremediation, they will express nosZ modified with the amino acid sequences that target the proteins to the mitochondria matrix and inner periplasmic membrane of the mitochondria. The mitochondrion is the site of respiratory reduction in the cell, i.e., the site of oxygen consumption, and is analogous to the site of N2O reduction in denitrifying bacteria. This is a high-risk project, but with great potential benefits of global importance. With one year of funding, the project seeks to determine:
1. whether N2O reduction in whole plants is possible using current nosZ sequences and mitochondrial targeting sequences,
2. whether the putative helper genes in the nos operon, nosXDFYL, are necessary for optimal N2OR expression, and
3. whether N2OR expressing plants can prevent N2O emissions from fertilized soils.
If N2OR can be made to be active in plants and if this technology is applied on a large scale to crops such as maize and rice, it is expected that N2O emissions from grain cultivation could be cut significantly, resulting in a sudden reduction in N2O increases. Potentially this reduction could be accomplished sustainably with little to no additional energy expenditure. This would be a major and welcome cut in greenhouse gas and ozone depleting emissions, unanticipated by present IPCC projections.

por.por_cntn:
A biotechnology that prevents the emission of an important greenhouse gas, nitrous oxide (N2O), from agricultural fields is being developed in our laboratory. We genetically engineered yeast and tobacco plants to express the bacterial enzyme N2O reductase in mitochondria where we expect it function as it does in bacteria to break down N2O to harmless N2.

Tobacco transformation vectors were constructed with the gene for type I NosZ structural unit fused to three different polypeptide sequences for the inner-membrane space of plant mitochondria. Additional vectors were constructed with the green fluorescent protein (GFP) fused to polypeptide targeting sequences. Initial experiments have shown that the GFP-tagged protein can be successfully targeted to the plant mitochondria. We tested transformed plants for N2O uptake and for N2 production using argon atmospheres and novel gas chromatographic techniques, but were unable to detect N2O degradation.

In addition, using yeast as a model organism, we have constructed plasmids with the nosZ sequence fused to targeting sequences for the intermembrane space targeting polypeptide on the N terminus and a HA tag sequence on the C terminus. Fractionation of the yeast mitochondria and immunoblots with antibodies to the HA tag has shown that NosZ protein was correctly located in the mitochondrial inner-membrane space as it is in bacteria analog, the periplasm. These techniques give us the basis for a full proposal that would have as its goal the reconstruction of the nos system in yeast mitochondria.

In order to predict how much impact this technology might have on emissions of N2O from agricultural fields, which are the main sources of this important greenhouse gas, we have constructed a model. Our calculations show that if N2O reductase can be made to work well in plant mitoc[SS1] hondria, it could prevent N2O emissions from fertilized crop fields and directly remove significant amounts of N2O from the atmosphere. Since N2O has 298 times the global warming potential as CO2, such genetically engineered crops could significantly slow down anthropogenic global warming and reverse the threat to the ozone layer.

 [SS1]
